did.unittitle: American Philosophical Society editorial and publications records

bioghist.p: Founded in 1743 by Benjamin Franklin, the American Philosophical Society was the first learned society in the United States. The Publications Department of the American Philosophical Society publishes Transactions, a highly respected series of monographs, five of which are currently published each year; Memoirs, books of various lengths in many scholarly disciplines; a quarterly journal, the Proceedings, which includes papers read at the Society's biannual meetings, independent essays sent to the American Philosophical Society by outside scholars, and biographical memoirs of Society members; and an annual Yearbook, which includes a listing of resident and foreign members, the President's Annual Message, the Report of the Executive Officers, and the Society's charter and laws. Manuscripts are reviewed by the Committee on Publications, which meets three times a year.

scopecontent.p: The bulk of this material consists of correspondence related to both accepted and declined submissions, including acknowledgment of receipt of manuscripts, rejections and acceptances, copyright documents, and reviewer's reports. There are multiple chronological groupings, but files tend to be alphabetical by author or article subject within each grouping. The collection contains financial documentation, including sales records from 1939 to 1972 and 1994 to 1996, publications inventory from 1935 to 1960, a cash book from 1955 to 1963, and purchase orders/invoices, royalty payments, and publication costs. Other administrative files include permissions to quote publications, topical files on the Yearbook, circulars, advertising, correspondence with printers and publishers (primarily invoices and quarterly statements), and minutes, agendas, and ballots from the Committee on Publications. The collection also includes card files for Transactions 33-61, Proceedings 114-119, and declined authors; a small number of manuscripts, including a camera-ready manuscript for Public Organization in Ancient Greece by Nicholas F. Jones; and editorial and general correspondence files (1922-1926) from the office of Arthur W. Goodspeed, Secretary.
